citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 6-year-old male wolf was observed with patchy hair loss in the left and right flank areas with reddish discoloration of the
fur. The skin in these areas appear red and inflamed. The wolf was seen randomly biting, scratching, and chewing at both
flank areas multiple times during the inspection and pacing around the primary enclosure in obvious agitation and
discomfort. The wolf was also seen rolling around on the ground to scratch the affected areas. When inquiring with the
facility representative about this condition he stated the wolf has been treated by the AV for this condition in the past. Last
year the wolf was prescribed two different medications that appeared to improve his symptoms temporarily while on
treatment but has not been on any therapy for several months. When asked if the AV has been contacted as the condition
appears to have worsened the representative was not able to provide any documentation of this communication. The
attending veterinarian was contacted to discuss the wolf’s condition and he stated there has been no communication from
the facility for this animal since October 2023 where it was stated that the wolf was improving on therapy. The wolf does
have a history of self-mutilation according to the attending veterinarian which is suspected to be due to underlying
neurologic or musculoskeletal disease.
Failure to provide adequate veterinary care and treat conditions that have worsened such as neurological disease which
have resulted in secondary skin trauma from self-mutilation can cause unnecessary distress, pain, secondary infections,
and negatively affect the animal’s health and well-being. The licensee must have this animal examined by a licensed
veterinarian so that an accurate diagnosis can be made, and an appropriate treatment plan can be developed and
followed. The licensee must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times by providing the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Corrected by 14 August 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
